div.p: 1. V.15. Wednesday.

Charles went into Boston, and took John Quincy with him. William Spear came with Elijah Baxter; we went in Spear’s Carryall to Mr Harmon’s, and taking him with us walked to my Ruggles and Thayer woodlot in the 600 Acres: we walked through the woods over it, and saw numerous stumps of trees which have been cut down, and carried away by despoilers to whom they were convenient— I desired Mr Spear to make sale of the wood upon about half of the lot, about the first week in next Month— And I agreed with him to visit the Verchild lot, next Tuesday if the weather should be fair; and if not, the first fair day afterwards— We picked up about a pack of fine chesnut Oak Acorns fallen from the trees, and found scarcely any others, excepting of the scrub oak, two bushes of which were covered with fruit. It began to sprinkle before we left the woods, and blew a heavy South-west gale with warm light showers all the remainder of the day and evening— Returning home, I found Lieutt. T. B Adams and his Sister Elizabeth here— They dined with us; and Elizabeth stays to pass the night here— My wife convalesces slowly, and both the Doctors were here this morning— I planted a row of chesnut Oak Acorns, with Peach stones and whole St. Germain Pears this afternoon—but the rain soon compelled me to quit the Garden— In the Evening I wrote part of a Letter in answer to Benjamin Pickman.
2. IV:45 Thursday

Walk to Braintree on the old Weymouth Road; and by the cross road to the Weymouth Turnpike returning over the Trask and Prospect hill. I gathered a few Shagbark walnuts, and only one Trask Pear— Scarcely any of them are left— The weather was nearly at Summer heat. E. Price Greenleaf brought me this afternoon a Quart of white Beech nuts, and White Oak Acorns— The Doctors were here, and Mrs Adams though able to leave her bed only for a small part of the day, is so much recovered that Dr Holbrook proposes now to discontinue his professional visits— I was so much engaged in reading Marshall and the Remembrancer, and Jefferson’s Correspondence for the Chronological order of Events in La Fayette’s life, that I found time scarcely to write half a page Alpheus Spear was here and settled with me for his Quarter’s Rent— He made me a proposition also; with regard to the Parish tax on the Mount Wollaston Estate which I incline to accept— I transplanted from Pot 1. a seedling Plum tree, and four Apple trees, in a row immediately North of Mary Louisa’s Nectarine and Peach, near the old Saint Germain Pear-tree. Elizabeth C. Adams went home this Morning— In the Evening I finished my answer to Benjamin Pickman.
3. IV. Friday

I walked before breakfast to the North side of Neponset Bridge; with the view to rectify my measurement of distance by time and by the number of my paces. I walked with as quick a pace as I could sustain, for several miles and found by pacing and repacing the space between the 5th. 6th and 7th. Milestones, that it takes 1070 of my paces to a mile, and 17 minutes 8 seconds of time, equalling 3 1/2 miles to an hour— This is for cool weather, and a good level road— And I could venture to measure the road from my gate to the Boston free Bridge by that rule, without displacing one of the milestones to the extent of five feet.— I ascertained also the distance to the North side of Neponset river which is 45 1/2 paces short of 2 Miles, and 3 quarters— I was out one hour and 36 minutes— Lieutt. T. B Adams and his brother John Quincy were here in the Evening; going to Boston to-morrow— In the garden I worked
languidly— Filled Pot one for the next Spring: and planted a row of Chesnut Oak Acorns, and White Beech seeds in the Nectarine Patch where I had already planted decayed peaches and plums— My proper occupation was still neglected, and I was from drowsiness unable to read or write in the Evening— My average pace, I find to be 59.215 inches; and I go rather faster than one step to a second.
4. IV. Saturday.

My admeasurement of the distance between the 7th. and 5th. Milestones, by which I find that it takes upon the average 1070 of my paces to a mile on level ground and a good dry road enabled me to rectify former approximations to correctness— By this new standard I found that from my gate to the Apthorp house is 1. mile—to the Braintree and Quincy line stone 2 to the gate below S. Capen’s house 3. to Eb and Josiah Adams’s gate 4. to the Scotland pond gate 5. and across the hills to my gate 7 furlongs 7 Rods and 3 feet—a walk for me of 1 hour and 40 minutes; but as I stop’d nearly half an hour to gather white Oak Acorns I was upwards of two hours out on my walk. The acorns were from one of two large white oak trees in the middle pasture; and are large and fair of their kind— In order to plant some of the white Oak Acorns immediately I passed much of the morning after breakfast in my garden; and put them in the ground between a seedling black-walnut and a wild cherry, near the honey-locust. I have so often failed in ascertaining the identity of the plants, with the seeds sown, that I constantly vary my expedients to accomplish it, and one of my curiosities now, is to mark specially the manner in which the white Oak first comes from the ground, and its habits of the first and second Season— I think it has but one growth in the year—in April and May; and then very small and slender— The Chesnut, red, and English Oaks, have two growths in a Summer, and their progress is proportionally rapid— With the Acorns I buried also some Beech seeds, and St. Michael Pear seeds, with 3 white crab apple seeds from Stoney field hill— Transplanted three Apple-seedlings from the Eastern close box, to the border in front of my chamber window, where I have now six Seedling Shellbark walnuts growing of a row of 12. that I planted in 1830. and not one of them is yet six inches high— After clearing the box, and spading up the earth in it I planted in a cross row 5 Trask Pear-seeds, with two white Oak Acorns, and 3 Beech seeds in it— And this Seedsman’s work so swallowed up the day, with visits from my Tenant Carr, who complained of a charge, of cabbaging my wood, and talked politics, and from Mr Thomas Loring and Mr Edward Thaxter from Hingham, that I found not a quarter of an hour to write; and when I attempted it in the Evening soon found it impracticable— There was heavy rain in the afternoon and Evening— Mary-Louisa was again severely afflicted with the ear ache, and aggravated with anxiety the disease of her grandmother, who was able to sit up but a small portion of the day.
5. IV. Sunday.

Walk round by the Neponset cross road which I now find to be short of 5 1/2 miles— To J. Hall’s first red Barn door 1 mile to Gulliver’s brook 2 to the . . . house 3 to the Slater’s house 4. to the empty house 5. and to my gate 515 paces—the measurement of time continues at 17 minutes a mile, and with allowance of half a minute to make 3 1/2 miles an hour— Heard Mr Whitney who administered the Communion, and preached in the Morning from Galatians 4.4 [“]But when the fulness of the time was come, God sent forth his Son”—and in the afternoon from Luke 12.4. “And I say unto you, my friends, Be not afraid of them that kill the body, and after that have no more that they can do 5. But I will forewar you whom you shall fear: Fear him which, after he hath killed, hath power to cast into hell; yea, I say unto
you, fear him.” The new choir of female singers, twenty or more enlivened the services. Mr Whitney gave notice that Mr Lucius Manlius Sargeant, would at seven O’Clock this Evening deliver a Lecture upon Temperance at the Episcopal Church— Louisa C. Smith dined with us. In the Evening I walked home with her— Paid a short visit at Mr Edward Miller’s. He is to remove tomorrow with his family into Boston for the Winter. I visited also at Mrs T. B. Adams’s—her Son John Quincy is to embark to-morrow, on board the Potowmack frigate— At seven O’Clock I attended at the Episcopal Church and found Mr Leach the Minister, reading Prayers, after which Mr Sargeant delivered his Lecture, about two hours in length. The auditory respectable in numbers manifested no impatience— The discourse was lively, satirical, and most earnest in the temperance cause— Its principal object was to render odious the rumsellers, among whom he said there were a great multitude of Deacons— He most earnestly urged his auditory never to vote for an intemperate man, as a candidate for any political Office— His delivery bating much affectation of manner was very good— There was a hymn sung and Mr Leach closed the meeting with a hymn— I walked home and found it near ten O’Clock— The Auditory were numerous, and the house was well filled. A meeting of the Temperance Society was announced for to-morrow Evening, at the Town-Hall.
6. IV:15 Monday

Walk to the Mount Wollaston farm, and found by the new measurement of my paces 1070 to a mile that the third mile from my gate, is on the Germantown road, at a single Oak tree at the West side of the road and beyond the bounds of my land— I found a number of Mookernuts as they are called by Michaux, or White Walnuts by Dr Bigelow. Juglans alba, or tomentosa— They are not yet ripe: and Michaux says they are ripe about the 15th. of November— I found very few black oak Acorns, none apparently good— Returning by my young Mount Wollaston Orchard, planted 23. Octr. and 6. and 20. Novr 1830., I found most of the Apple-trees, in very indifferent and unpromising condition— The border of forest trees has almost totally failed on three sides—but on the West side, along the brow of the hill there are several Walnuts, Chesnut Oaks, and especially chesnuts which in 25 years from this time may form a grove, and in 50 a thick and tall forest. Alteri Seculo must be the motto of the man who plants forest or even most fruit trees. Kirk transplanted for me this afternoon 8 Peach seedlings from the Nursery to the close East of the house— I have little hope that any of them will live; but by planting Peach stones, Apple and Pear seeds in the grounds around them, I hope to raise a choice of Stock trees on the spots where they will come up— This experiment first made last year was partially successful, and I shall repeat it, as long as I am able to visit or superintend my garden. I planted also a number of Endicott and Sickel Pear seeds; with precautions to enable me to recognize the plants of such seeds as may come up. Dr Holbrook and Dr Woodward were here. Mrs Adams is better; but was much distressed by a Letter this day received from her sister Mrs Frye, mentioning that both our Son John and his wife, are very ill; confined with chills and fevers— She had also a Letter from Walter Hellen, of last Thursday at New-York— He had a very long and bad passage from Providence— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here this forenoon His brother John Quincy, left home to embark in the frigate Potowmack. It is through my agency that he has obtained this opportunity of entering upon an useful and honorable profession— Will a kind Providence smile upon the result? Charles came out from Boston before dinner— My day was again wasted.
7. IV:15. Tuesday.

Charles returned this morning to Boston— William Spear called at 8 O’Clock and I went with him and viewed my Verchild and Atherton Pasture, which is rapidly becoming a Woodlot— There is on a part of it a considerable growth of White-Birch, which I have been much advised to sell off as it stands; but which would sell for almost nothing; and there is growing with them a goodly number of Hickory Walnuts, Oaks and Maples which if suffered to grow a few years more will make valuable trees— I thought it most advisable to have the Birch and perhaps the cedars cut away, and leave the other forest trees to grow— I visited also the grove on the brow of the hill opposite the house in which I was born, and found there a number of fine Oaks and Walnuts; but scarcely any nuts or acorns. One black Oak only I found bearing very full but the Acorns are not yet ripe. There were two cows of Mr Wilde who hires the adjoining lot, in the close, and evidence that there had been horses there— And no small number of stumps disclosed the fact, that the neighbours had freely supplied themselves with fire wood from the same grounds— These are depredations against which it is perhaps impossible to guard. How much the eye of the master is wanting I can perceive by what I discover even in my morning walks— I agreed with Spear to go into the woods with him again next Tuesday; if the weather should be fair— I returned home about one O’Clock, and Mrs Adams soon after returned from a ride—the first time she has been out for a full month— Louisa Foster, dined at Mrs T. B. Adams’s and was out till Evening— I intermitted my garden visit and plantations, and gave the afternoon and part of the evening to writing— First morning fire in my Library, for the Season.
8. IV. Wednesday.

Walk to Germantown ferry which I now find to be 3 miles and 3 quarters from my gate— On my return I spoke to Alpheus Spear about my Orchard and grove, in which I propose to plant more trees. I agreed with him to go there this day fortnight, if the weather should be fair— Along the fence on the Western side of the lot I counted 168 seedling Chesnut Walnut and Chesnut Oak trees from the nuts and walnuts which I planted in 1830— The trees are now beyond the reach of frost and Sun, and have lived through all my neglect and ignorance;—and in spite of Alpheus Spear’s horses, which he has turned in among them,—My experiment promises to be eminently successful, though it is known only to the Supreme disposer of Events who will derive the benefit of it— Louisa C. Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams dined here— I had devoted the morning from breakfast till dinner to my task, but was again disappointed. Mr John Barney of Baltimore, with his daughter and Mr George Blake, and Mr Barney discoursed much upon the party on board of the Potowmac frigate to which he had invited my wife and me, but which we could not attend— He spoke also of having lately visited Mr Madison and of the soundness of his political opinions— In default of any other History of the French Revolution I had recourse to the Memoirs of the Life and reign of Frederic-William the 2d of Prussia, by the Count de Segur, which amused and occupied me, and wholly suspended my writing.— After dinner I planted the seeds of two Sickel Pears, with Apple-seeds, and white Oak Acorns in a row between a live and a dead seedling black walnut near the honey locust; and in a row 2 East of the old St. Germain Pear tree Chesnut and white Oak Acorns—Beech Seeds, Shagbarks—Pear, Apple and grape seeds— I found it necessary to dispose of as many of my chesnut oaks as I could, as many of them are already sprouting.
9. III.45. Thursday.

Walk to and upon the Railway— I was upwards of two hours out but my walk did not exceed 6 miles— I had some little difficulty in finding my way out from the Railway to the Harmer lane; and returned over the Trask hill— Charles and his wife came from Medford; dined with us and returned in the Evening; as Mr William Plumer junr from Boston— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here a few minutes before dinner, but declined to stay— It came on to rain about 1. O’Clock afternoon, and rained heavily till Evening— This was another day of disappointment to my occupations. Charles found me the Volumes of La Cretelle’s History of France containing the period immediately preceding the French Revolution— The weakness of my eyes allowed me to read only a few pages of it, and I could read nothing else— I wrote nothing. Mr. Plumer’s conversation was chiefly upon New-Hampshire Politics, in which or in any other Politics at this time, there is nothing of absorbing interest— The Prosperity of the Country, independent of all agency of the Government, is so great that the People have nothing to disturb them, but their own waywardness and corruption— They quarrel upon dissensions of a doit, and split up into gangs of partizans of A, B, C, and D, without knowing why they prefer one to another— Caucusses, County, State, and National Conventions Public dinners, and dinner table Speeches two or three hours long, constitute the operative power of electioneering, and the parties are of working men, temperance reformers, Antimasons, Union and State-rights men, nullifiers, and above all Jackson men—Van Buren men, Clay men, Calhoun men—Webster men, and M’Lean men—whigs and Tories, Republicans and Democrats, without one ounce of honest principle to chuse between them— New-Hampshire is governed by a knave of the name of Isaac Hill, Editor of a Newspaper, Mail contractor and now a Senator of the United States—just cunning enough to grow rich by railing against the reach, and to fatten upon the public spoils bawling Democracy— This is the begetting Sin of popular governments, and it is now as it always has been— Van Buren is a demagogue of the same School, with a tincture of Aristocracy, an amalgamated metal of lead and copper. There are five or six Candidates for the succession to the Presidency; all of them demagogues; and not one of them having any consistency of system for the Government of the Union. Plumer asked, as other have asked, whether they might not go back to the last Administration— They might as well ask the resurrection of one dead man to life by touching the bones of another—a miracle never repeated since it was seen at the Sepulchre of Elisha. I have nothing henceforth to look to but the grave, and if possible to withdraw from the public Scene, without waiting to be pushed from it— May it please the giver of all good from the disgrace of dishonouring my last days, by loitering too long upon the Stage.
10. III.45. Friday.

Heavy gale of wind from the Northwest all night— I walked out as the Clock struck 5. and walking against the gale, found the distance from my gate to the 7th. milestone 334 paces to the 6th. 1085. to the 5th. 1090 I then turned off to the right hand and walked round by the farms road, coming out by the Neponset corner a mile of 1080 paces + 200 to the corner and then 540 to the 6th. Milestone—but returning before the wind the distance from the 6th. to the 7th milestone was again 1070 paces, and thence to my gate 326— Louisa C. Smith came to spend a week or ten days with us— I was occupied part of the morning, and all the afternoon in planting seeds; Walnuts and Acorns—Peach and Plum Stones— First in Pot 17. where I chiefly try the experiment of the Trask wild Pear seeds—with large sweeting Apple seeds, Plum
stones broken, cherries steeped, a white Oak Acorn, a Shagbark walnut and an Ash seed— After dinner I planted a row from the Summer house cellar to a willow stump near the road—and half a row, in the border fronting the North fence of the Eastern close— Kirk planted three rows of seedling Apple-trees, from the Pomice at the Cyder-Press, in the garden fronting the Hazel-bushes— Lieutenant T. B. Adams was here this morning, and John Quincy this Evening— He walked out and is to stay till Monday— He has been upon duty on board the frigate, from last Monday, and appears to be well contented with his situation— Louisa C. Smith and Louisa Foster took tea at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— I wrote a page this Evening, and should have read another but for interruption— My wife’s recovery is very slow, and she can as yet sit up only part of the day.
11. V. Saturday.— Boston— Cambridge— Quincy.

Louisa Foster had determined to return home this morning, and Elizabeth C. Adams was to go in to Boston with her— I had been very desirous of obtaining the perusal of papers in possession of Mr Sparks relating to La Fayette, and particularly of his Correspondence with Washington, and with the French Government, of all which mention was made, by Edward Everett and of which he had availed himself largely in the composition of his Eulogy; a printed copy of which I received two days ago from him— It occurred to me before I rose from bed this morning that my best way to obtain the papers was to go this day to Cambridge where Sparks resides, and to ask the papers of himself— I went into Boston and after leaving the young Ladies at Mr James H. Foster’s I called at Charles’s Office where I saw him, and then immediately proceeded to Cambridge— Stopped at President Quincy’s; but he was at Boston, at a special meeting of the Corporation. I saw Mrs Quincy, and her daughters Susan and Anna— She sent a man with me to Mr Sparks’s house— He fortunately was at home, and promised to send me on Monday or Tuesday next, to be left at Cumings and Hilliard’s in Boston, all the Manuscripts that I desired; and also several printed French Memoirs of La Fayette, and Montgaillard’s history of the French Revolution— The Manuscripts are collections which Mr Sparks received from La Fayette himself, with whom he passed several weeks at La Grange; and who communicated to him many of the circumstances of his own history— I asked Mr Sparks whether he proposed to write and publish a Life of La Fayette— He said no—he had not time, for such a work— Most of the papers are yet in the possession of Mr Everett.— I returned immediately Boston—called again at Charles’s Office, and he promised to get the papers of Mr Sparks at Cumings and Hilliard’s on Monday or Tuesday and bring them out to me— I returned the visit of the late Lieutt. Governor T. L. Winthrop, and had some amusing conversation with him. He said that the object of La Fayette’s visit to this Country in 1784. was to communicate to General Washington the secret of Mesmer’s animal magnetism; and mentioned that he had at that time been present at a party, where La Fayette recommended to Mrs John R. Livingston who had been a Miss Sheaffe animal magnetism as a cure for a disease of the lungs— Mr. Winthrop once an Apollo Belvidere in person is now at 73 the wreck of a man— He told me he had been in not a house in Boston, other than his own, for the last twelve Months, save once, and that was a quarter of an hour before I came in— I called at Jones’s shop 123 Washington Street, and selected a Seal for the engraving of an Oak Acorn, and then went and dined at Mr James H. Foster’s— After dinner I went to the livery stable, where I found the Carriage—then went and at Mr Phineas Foster’s took up Elizabeth C. Adams and Ann Harrod who had come in this morning in the Steam-boat from Portland— After
calling again at Mr James H Foster’s for sundry emplettes, we came out to Quincy— I alighted at home with the dusk of Evening, and the young Ladies went on to Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I found John Quincy at my house, and he spent an hour of the Evening with me— A beautiful but cold autumnal day— I could not write— Evening in my wife’s chamber.
12. V. Sunday.

Walk on the Neponset Bridge road and round by the road to the farms— Morning clear and cold—road dry; no gale—marked the half-mile spots between the 7th. 6th. and 5th. milestones—one a bush East of the road, the other a stone on the East side at the Neponset cross road— I was out an hour and a half— Heard Mr Lunt, in the morning from John 16.33. “These things I have spoken to you that in me ye might have Peace.”— The Doctrine was that the only source of all peace of mind is religion. The afternoon text was from 1. John 3.7. “He that doeth righteousness is righteous even as he is righteous[”]— All righteousness therefore consists in beneficent action— Good deeds and righteousness are synonymous— I had read last Sunday morning, the 7th. Sermon of the 6th. volume of Saurin, on the family of Jesus Christ; and this morning I read the 8th. on the equality of men— There was so little to remark on the former that I had not noted my perusal of it; but the sermon upon the equality of men is admirable, and peculiarly interesting as having been delivered before this principle had become the central point of almost all political controversy— Lieutt. T. B. Adams, and his brother John Quincy were here after the service, and John Quincy took leave of us, to join his ship to-morrow Morning— I sent by him a note to Captain Nicholson, declining his invitation for to morrow at noon on board of the Frigate Potomac. I wrote this Evening part of a Letter to John B. Hearn at Chillicothe Ohio, in answer to one from him.
13 IV.45. Monday—

Walk to the middle and Druid Pastures, where I gathered about a quart of Chesnut white Oak and white Oak Acorns— They are just now ripe and loose from their cups. But the Black Oak Acorns will not be ripe in less than another week, or perhaps fortnight.— The Chesnut Oak Acorns, which I picked up, fallen from the trees on the first day of this Month in the woods were then ripe— I planted in the garden sixty of them that same day; and 20 more two days after— These I expect will many of them come up next Spring; but almost all the rest have sprouted before I was ready to plant them— I put into the ground last Friday and this day upwards of 100 with sprouts some of them an inch long, uncertain whether they will continue to vegetate underground or perish— The white and chesnut oak Acorns are the only ones which I have observed to sprout thus in the open air; and from this facility of vegetation it may be inferred that they may be easily raised. Of the Chesnut Oak my experience has confirmed this expectation: for of my seedlings of that kind, I see many, if not all have two growths every Summer— The white Oaks have but one; and that so slender that it is winter killed to the ground, for several successive years— Of many hundred white Oak Acorns planted by me in my garden and Nursery, I have only two ascertained white Oak seedlings growing— The Chesnut Oaks are numerous. This difference of about one month in the time when the Acorns of the several kinds of oaks growing here come to maturity, and the difference between the kinds which have two growths, and those which have only one in a Season, are both circumstances much to be noted by any one who would raise a forest of Oaks— I have learnt them by experience, and have no doubt that with a faculty of meditative observation tenfold greater than that which has been
allotted to me, every succeeding year would disclose to me some secret of vegetation from which inferences of public utility might be drawn— This afternoon was consumed in finishing to plant the row, the whole length of the North fence of the Eastern close—but I had been without interruption in the morning, and had written for leisure after dinner— My wife rode out the second time since her illness; but was much overcome by the effort of going to and coming from the Carriage— I wrote a short Letter to J. B. Hearn in the Evening.
14. IV.45. Tuesday

Rain, much in the Night, and change of weather to cold Northwester. Walk before Sunrise omitted— William Spear came, and I rode with him to a woodlot in the six hundred Acres, belonging to the heirs of my mother as one of the devisees of Norton Quincy— It was originally a lot of 83 Acres 3 Quarters 28 Rods—and was bequeathed by him to the heirs of his three Sisters Joanna Thaxter, Elizabeth Smith and Lucy Tufts— Cotton Tufts Executor of Norton Quincy’s Will sold off the wood, and then the Lot was set off in three parcels, one to Cotton Tufts junr. only son and heir of Lucy Tufts of 27 Acres 3 Quarters and 28 Rods, one to the heirs of Joanna Thaxter of 20. Acres and 2 Quarters, and one to the heirs of Elizabeth Smith 34 Acres— The heirs of Cotton Tufts junr still own his portion— The Thaxter portion has been sold, purchased by George W Beale— The portion of Elizabeth Smith, descended to her three daughters, Mary Cranch, Abigail Adams my mother, and Elizabeth Peabody— Asa French of Braintree purchased two or three years since the rights of the Cranch family, and by Petition to the Court of Common Pleas of Norfolk County had them set off to him in severalty about two years since, and last winter sold the wood upon it standing, and it has been cut off— W. Spear who is thoroughly acquainted with the lot went with me, and shewed me the bounds round the lot— I shall think next Summer, if life and health are spared me of having my portion set off to me in severalty— For which purpose I must ascertain from Asa French, or from the Registry of Deeds or Records of the Court of Common Pleas at Dedham, what portion has been set off to French—and then notify William Smith John Smith, John P. De Wint and his wife— Mr and Mrs Treadway, Alexander B. Johnson and his wife, and my brother Thomas’s widow and six children all of whom have an interest as heirs of my mother— There is no difficulty, though much complication in the process, now that I know where the land lies, which I never did before, and the condition of the title which had never been explained to me— The width of the lot remaining at the narrowest end as paced by me was 65 paces or 20 Rods— It was near two O’Clock when I got home— The distance from Harmon’s house to mine is about four miles; and from Harmon’s to the woodlot about half a mile— There were many Oak trees on the way, but I gathered a very few Acorns; chiefly of Pin Oak— Charles came out to dinner— In the afternoon I transplanted 7. dwarf Apple-seedlings from Pot8. Seedling Peartrees from Pot1. Cherry and 3 Appletrees from Pot2 Cherry trees from Potand one Althaea and one Cherry tree from PotIn all 23 Seedling trees, in one Row in the St. Germain Patch in the garden— Emptied the five Pots and filled them with fresh Earth— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here, and I spoke to him of this woodlot falling into dereliction, by the heirs of Norton Quincy— He promised to look into his fathers papers for further Evidence concerning it— I received this Evening from Mr Sparks a large box containing books and papers relating to La Fayette— Evening cold spent in conversation with Charles and Lieutt. T. B. Adams.
15. Wednesday. IV.

Fahrenheit at 24. Sharp frost— Walk to the Henry Hardwick woodlot, and found the Solitary Black Oak-tree, bearing perhaps half a peck of Acorns— They are not yet ripe, and I gathered about one pint to be gathered a week or fortnight hence if then on the tree— I think their time for being perfectly ripe will be the last of October, and that they will be of the best kind for planting— I found a new road across the Hills coming out by the Apthorp house, opposite; and walked round by Mrs T. B. Adams’s house— She threw up her window and spoke to me— From her door to my gate is 1100 paces— Mr. Peter Mackintosh called on me with a Mr Marsh, and left with me his papers to sustain his claim for a pension, to which I must attend as soon after I reach Washington as possible. President Quincy likewise called up me— He spoke of the present condition of the University as satisfactory; but while his words were cheering, his tone was dejected— He can never regain his popularity with the Students, and the public treat him as they treat all old men, with cold neglect and insulting compassion— He is not made of stuff to struggle long against this— Lieutt. T. B. Adams brought me sundry papers relating to that woodlot belonging to the heirs of the devisees of Norton Quincy, which I examined, and must lay aside to take up if possible next Spring— Also other papers relating to the family Lands in Vermont— Mr Gourgas has settled his account of Administration upon my brother’s Estate. Charles left us this afternoon to return to Medford— I gave him the white Oak Acorns and leaves, and the Volume of Michaux containing the white Oak plate; for the engraver of my proposed Seal— Of my planting, I only filled one Pot.with Trask Pear Seeds, Dexter Apple seeds—one black Oak, one white Oak Acorn 1 Ash-seeds, and five kernels of Plums— I made a strong but fruitless effort to write, this Evening.
16 Thursday IV.

Sharp frost again and a cold morning— I walked to the mount Wollaston beach, to a solitary tree 65 paces beyond three Miles— Returning I met Alpheus Spear, and told him I should come next Wednesday, if the weather should be fair to work at my Orchard and future grove— I measured by pacing, the corner stone of the Neponset Bridge Turnpike marked 7 1/4 miles 50 Rods from the Boston Bridge free—to the 7th. mile-stone—and found the distance 435 paces, which at 1070 paces to a mile is 1/4 of a mile and 50 Rods exactly— I was out 1 hour and 49 minutes, at 17 minutes to a mile making the walk six Miles and about 2/5 of a mile. The cold weather quickened my pace, and I walked away the numbness of my left hand fingers; but not entirely that of the right hand fingers. Lieutenant Thomas B. Adams came and took leave— His furlough being about to expire, and he is returning to his Post at the Allegheny Arsenal, near Pittsburgh— His mother goes with him to visit Mrs De Wint at Fishkill Landing— They left home at 4 this afternoon, to go tomorrow Morning from Boston by the Steamboat from Providence to New-York— Elizabeth C. Adams came to spend a few days with us— I gave the Lieutt. a power of Attorney from me to Luther Angier of Medford, to leave the Estates at Medford, and this town, that were my brother’s: to receive the rents and pay them over to Mrs T. B. Adams for five years, if she should live so long— He left with me the papers relating to the hotchpot woodlot , and to the Vermont lands, for me to look into them next Spring, if I should live and have the time. Of the great box of books
relating to La Fayette, sent me by Mr Sparks, I read one pamphlet catchpenny life of the General by Chateauneuf; part of a Volume of Montgaillard’s History of France from the end of the reign of Louis the 16th. and part of the manuscript correspondence of La Fayette with the Count de Vergennes— I read much, and of course wrote little—less than half a page— Mr Beale and his daughter Ann were here this Evening.
17. V. Friday.

Short walk of forty minutes before breakfast; and then devoted the whole uninterrupted day to reading and writing, at the expence of my garden and Nursery labours. I found the Oak and Tupelo trees in Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s land, entirely strip’d of their fruit, which they had on them at my last visit the 21st. of last Month. I only filled one of my Earthen Pots with Acorns and seeds— My attention has been attracted to the different appearance of the first shoots of the different kinds of Oaks and Walnuts as they come out of the ground— The first leaves of most of them are altogether different from those which afterwards come out; and from my observations hitherto, I cannot discern of what kind the tree will be from its first foliage— I now plant in several of my Pots a black Oak, white Oak and chesnut Oak Acorn with intent to observe how they will severally come up—and with them Ash, Beech, Apple and Pear seeds, and Plum stones and kernels.— I read much of La Fayette’s Correspondence with the Count de Vergennes, and several passages of the Abbé de Montgaillard’s History, and of Regnault-Warin’s life of La-Fayette— Wrote two pages of my own Discourse; and finished a Letter to Dr. Waterhouse— I ought to do every day as much.
18. IV.15 Saturday

I wrote this morning, without walking out, before Breakfast— Immediately after, William Spear came and said that Lemuel Brackett made some question about the bounds of the Ruggles and Thayer woodlot, upon which I had determined to sell the wood standing— I gave him the two Deeds to my father from William Adams and his wife, and from Ebenezer Thayer, containing the description of the bounds, and the plan of survey, made by Asa French, to shew to Mr Brackett— I went with Kirk to the Mount Wollaston farm, and examined the Orchard of Apple-trees which I set out in 1830, and the grove of chesnut and Oak trees growing from nuts and acorns then planted round its borders— I agreed with Spear to set out some more trees, and to plough up the ground on the Eastern border where none of the plants from the seed of 1830 has survived; though there are nearly three hundred trees on the three other sides— I came home and dined— Immediately after dinner, Charles came in from Boston, having a Letter from Walter Hellen, written Wednesday Evening, saying that my Son John was extremely ill, and urging that if his mother could not come on, Charles or I should come immediately— It was necessary to communicate this to my dear wife, whose distress was agonizing, and who though unable to walk across her chamber long insisted upon going immediately, herself
to Washington— I determined to go myself to-morrow; to take the Boat from Providence on Monday; and I sent immediately for Dr Holbrook, who came and assured my wife that it was impossible she should go to Washington, in the present state of her health, and that the attempt would be at the hazard of her life— She became herself convinced it would be so, and was partially tranquilised— The Doctor did not apprehend any further effect upon her of this dreadful shock, but he had not been an hour gone, when she was seized with excessive sickness, faintings and cramps— I sent for him again and he came at nine this Evening— After some time the extreme sickness subsided and he promised to come again early to-morrow Morning— [symbols]
19. IV. Sunday. To Boston— Tremont House

Read from the 13th. to the 16th. Chapter of Acts in C. Thomson’s translation of the New Testament. Wrote the Diary of yesterday and a short answer to an invitation from the Adelphi Union Society of Williams College at Williamstown to deliver an Oration before them, on the eve of their next Commencement; which I declined— After breakfast I was occupied all the morning in packing up for my departure. After dinner I attended Meeting, and heard Mr Lunt, from Matthew 11.28. “Come unto me, all ye who labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.” A text, and a Sermon in which there was something soothing and consolatory— Dr Holbrook had called this morning, and found my dear wife somewhat tranquilized; but my parting from her was heart rending. Dr Holbrook told me he did not believe there ever was formed a human being of deeper and acuter sensibility— I left her at four this afternoon— Louisa C. Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams remaining with her— I came with Charles into Boston, and took a Chamber at the Tremont House— Wilson came in an hour after with my baggage and John Kirk who is to go with me. Soon after my arrival, Felix Grundy a member of the Senate of the United States from Tennessee sent me his card— He is chairman of the Committee of the Senate, upon the affairs of the General Post-Office, authorised to sit during the recess of the Senate, and is here upon that business. I must content myself with returning his visit by card— P. P. F. Degrand came in with Charles They had been to the Post-Office, where on a second call Charles found and obtained the Letter from Mrs Frye to my wife, mentioned in Walter Hellen’s Letter to Charles, received yesterday. Mrs Frye’s Letter was written the day before Walter’s that is last Tuesday— And now there was one of a day later than Walter’s, from Thomas B. Johnson to me, in which he speaks of my Son John’s illness, as pronounced by Dr Huntt to be critical— But he adds that since Sunday the symptoms had varied so as to occasion alternately alarm and encouragement. From this word my anxious imagination spun out a thread of hope, but the three Letters written on three successive days exhibit no cheering prospect of relief— Just before eight O’Clock Charles left me to go by the Stage to Medford— Degrand remained with me till near Nine— I wrote a page, for occupation, if possible to relieve the deep affliction of my Soul. I feel the duty and the difficulty of resignation to the Will of God— I invoke his mercy, profoundly conscious as I am of my own unworthiness to obtain it— And still cherish hope, where hope is without rational support.
20. V. Monday— From Boston to Providence— Steamer Benjamin Franklin— Sound.

After breakfasting at the Tremont-house, I took my seat in the Pilot Stage to Providence— Its departure was at half past six of the morning, and at Noon the passengers passed from the Stage into the Steamboat Benjamin Franklin Captain Coleman— I had five fellow passengers in the Stage besides John Kirk— Mrs Stuart and her daughter Delia were of the number. It had rained all Night, and continued to rain till past ten of the morning— The Stage leaked from the top from which I received a dripping of the moisture—and it drove me to change my seat— In the Steam-boat there were a multitude of passengers of whom I recognized prior acquaintance in T. W. Ward, Treasurer of Harvard University, last week returned from a short visit to England, and Thomas Arnott a Quaker preacher who called upon me at Quincy on the 14th. of last July. Others claimed acquaintance with me, whom I did not recollect—of whom a Son of Mr John Parker of Boston was one— He said he had been several years an inhabitant of the State of New-York: in the interior, on the borders of Hudson’s river— There was much conversation this evening among the Passengers upon religious and political topics in which I took a part. Much discussion upon the controverted character and divinity of Christ, and much upon the Slave question, the prospects of universal emancipation, and the intellectual capacity of the African race. These Conversations were continued till past midnight—to the annoyance of one whom they roused from seep in his cot— A wind at N.N.W. had before Sunset swept off all the clouds, and the evening was smooth and mild with clear moonlight.
21. VI. Tuesday— New-York, Amboy— Bordentown— Philadelphia.

I had scarcely an hour of Sleep in the night— Landed from the Boat at the foot of Courtland Street, New-York at seven O’Clock, and breakfasted at the City-Hotel— Met there Peter Force and Joseph Gales from Washington; but not within the last week, and they could give me no tidings— I wrote and despatched a Letter for Charles, and at ten O’Clock took the Steam-boat to Amboy—thence in three hours by the Railway to Bordentown, and then by the other Steamboat to Philadelphia, where I arrived at seven in the Evening, and took a chamber at the United States Hotel—wrote a second Letter to Charles. I had a company of fellow passengers almost totally different from those between Providence and New-York— Among those of this day were William B. Lawrence, and John B. Murray of New-York—a Mr Ephraim Adams of Fredericksburg Virginia, and a Quaker’s whose name did not reach me, but who had been in the boat from Newport— He introduced again the subject of Slavery, and emancipation, and the capacity of the Negro race. Mr Lawrence and Mr Murray had conversation more suited to my disposition— Lawrence is going to Washington upon business relating to the indemnity Treaty with France. Mr Murray goes to Baltimore, on account of the illness of Lloyd N. Rogers’s wife, the daughter of George Hay, and Grand daughter of President Monroe— Murray says he fears she is in a decline— Lawrence came with me to the United States Hotel.
22. V:30. Wednesday— From Philadelphia to Washington—

At Seven O’Clock this morning we parted from the Chesnut Street wharf at Philadelphia in the Steamboat Robert Morris— Landed at Newcastle at ten, passed in the Rail-road Car in one hour to Frenchtown— Then took the Steamboat
Charles Carroll of Carrollton, Captain Chaytor, to Baltimore— We landed there at 4. in the afternoon, and Lieutenant Bartlett of the Engineers collected a sufficient number of Passengers, for a Stage to Washington. Mr Lawrence, and Joel B. Sutherland, one of the members of Congress from Philadelphia, were of the company— As we approached the half-way house near the Bridge over the Patuxent the two leaders with the pole, and fore-wheels of another Stage coming from Washington ran full tilt up, and struck the pole of our Carriage in front. The other Stage had overset at a bad place almost impossible to pass— My fellow Passengers and I walked to the half-way house, where we were to change horses, and as we passed by the spot where the other Carriage was overset, we thought it had saved us from the same accident— This delayed us about an hour—and it was just ten O’Clock, when I alighted at the House of my Son John, at Washington— William C. Greenleaf came to the door, and as I came out of the Carriage, I asked how my Son was—he said—very low. Mrs Frye received me in the drawing-room; and Mr Frye in my chamber.— Mrs Frye advised me at first not to see him till the morning, but afterwards changed her mind, and thought it best I should see him before retiring to bed— I sent for Dr Huntt in the middle of the Night— He came, and advised me to see him— I went to his bed-side twice, and saw and heard him; he had no consciousness of any thing on Earth— His wife was in bed in the upper chamber, very sick herself—on seeing me she burst into tears— I promised her that I would be a father to her and her children— Finding myself much exhausted and unwell, I retired at 2 in the morning to bed—
23. IV:30. Thursday.

At half past four I rose again, and going into the bed-chamber where my Son lay, found Mr Frye, closing his eyes— He had just ceased to breathe— May God in his infinite mercy have received him to the joys of Heaven! Of the day from that time I have no distinct recollection— In a state between stupefaction, and a nervous irritation aggravated by the exertion to suppress it, the effort of my Soul was a deep, and earnest and unceasing supplication to God, for the Spirit and the will to fulfil all the duties devolving upon me, by this event; and for the blessing of Almighty God upon this purpose— Mr Frye, whose devotion to my dear child, during all his illness has been unbounded, undertook to make all the necessary arrangements for the funeral— My dear Son had been in a declining and drooping state of health more than three years— Several times afflicted with severe and acute disease; often so far recovered as to be out—able to travel and attend to business but never well— I left him here on the 5th. of last July with earnest intreaty that he would come with his family, and spend the Summer at Quincy— He did make arrangements to go in September, when first his wife and then himself were successively taken down with intermittent fevers— His case did not however present symptoms of danger, till Sunday the 12th. of this Month, from which time, there has been no rational hope of his recovery— Mrs Frye wrote to my dear wife to apprize us of his danger on Wednesday the 15th. Walter Hellen the next day— Mr T. B. Johnson the day after, and Mr Frye last Sunday to me— Walter’s Letter was the first received, and upon the receipt of that I came on— His disease was rapidly proceeding to its fatal termination—last Friday, being in perfect possession of his mind, and distinctly foreseeing
the event, he dictated to Mr Frye, in the presence of Mrs Good, various dispositions relating to his property, and his persons— He particularly desired that his body might be only be deposited here, until it can be transported to Quincy— Conformably to this desire Mr Frye applied to Coll. George Bomford the proprietor of Kalorama, for permission temporarily to deposit the remains in the vault at that place to which he readily agreed— Mr Frye wrote notes also to William A Bradley, P. R. Fendall William Ramsay, H. L. Randall, W. W. Seaton and Benjamin O. Tayloe inviting them to attend the funeral as Pall bearers at 3 O’Clock on Saturday afternoon— They all accepted, but Mr Bradley who is obliged to be absent at Baltimore on that day— His brother Joseph H. Bradley was invited in his place and accepted— Mr Frye applied also to Mr William Hawley, Rector of St. John’s Church, and the Revd. Edward Smith Pastor of the second Presbyterian Church, requesting them to officiate as Clergymen, at the interment which both promised to do— I was desirous of inviting also Mr Cazneau Palfrey the Pastor of the unitarian church here to unite in the Solemnities, but on consulting with the two other Clergymen we thought it most advisable to assign the religious performances only to them— The ordinary funeral arrangements were referred to the Undertaker Kripps—and a short obituary notice was sent to the Offices of the National Intelligencer, the Telegraph and the Globe— It was published in the Telegraph of this afternoon— I wrote to my beloved wife, and to my only surviving Son, communicating to them this heavy dispensation of the Providence of God. I controuled as far as I was able the unutterable anguish of my own Soul, endeavouring to sooth the yet more aggravated affliction of his widowed wife— Reduced and emaciated by sickness herself, she suffers in body and in mind; above all at her own inability to render to her beloved and affectionate husband in the extremes of his last illness the tender attentions and good Offices which smooth the pillow of death— Johnson Hellen called here in the course of the day—and William C. Greenleaf— Walter Hellen went to his mother at Alexandria, with promise to return tomorrow— Mr and Mrs Frye remained here the whole day, and he will pass here the Night— He also wrote at my request to my Son Charles.
24. V. Friday.

The day passed like that of yesterday almost unconsciously to myself—with an agonizing heart, a perpetually aggravating sense of the calamity that has befallen me—an inability to realize its extent—a galling consciousness that it can never be repaired, and an unceasing recollection of all the precious services that my darling child had rendered me—his discharge of all his filial duties, his kindness, his affection, his devotion to all my interests, and all my desires—the uncomplaining patience with which he has endured misfortune, sickness and disappointment the hardness of his fate, and the meekness with which he has submitted to it—even his infirmities— Oh! let me not murmur at the will of God— Let me cast myself and him upon the mercies of an omnipotent creator and preserver; let me believe, that for suffering upon Earth there is compensation in Heaven, and that there, the tears of sorrow are wiped away, and that every virtue shall be blessed with its reward— My child—my child— In the bosom of your God, may never ending joys—joys unspeakable and full of glory, cancel all the sufferings, of which your portion was so great here below, and may it one day be the blessed destiny of your Parents to enjoy them with you.
The Preparations for the funeral of my Son, continued under the indefatigable assiduity and active exertions of Mr Frye, who after passing with him the last Night of his life and closing his eyes, passed again the last Night with a neighbour Mr Haskell, in watching over his body— The arrangements are all made for its preservation so that it may hereafter be transported according to his desire to Quincy— I saw him, while he was yet living and in the last struggle of life— I saw, and kissed his lifeless brow yet warm and all but animate— I saw him last evening laid out in his shroud, and this day in the last receptacle of his form— The brow was placid in death as it had been in life— There was no trace of agony upon it; nor had there been throughout his illness a disordered muscle upon his face— Bodily disease and silent Sorrow were all that preyed upon his form, and his death was tranquil—undisturbed by any conscious pang of voluntary wrong— Mr Hawley the Clergyman, and judge Cranch visited me this day—to judge Cranch and his family, as my near relatives the only special invitation of attendance at the funeral was sent— I wrote this day a long Letter to my Son Charles, in fulfilment of the first of the duties which the decease of his brother has brought upon me, and for the entire performance of which I implore a blessing from above—but I scarcely know what I wrote— Walter Hellen came up from Alexandria, and I invited him to remain here with us until my Son Charles shall come, or we shall have made further arrangements for the winter, to which he readily consented— William C. Greenleaf also came at 9 O’Clock this Evening, and they will watch this Night.
25. V. Saturday.

At three O’Clock this afternoon the funeral of my ever lamented son, John Adams took place from his house in the City of Washington— A short address and appropriate prayer was made at the house, by Mr Smith the Pastor of the second Presbyterian Church; after which a procession of Carriages, followed the herse to the vault at Kalorama, where the body was deposited in a state and enclosures suited to removal at the convenient Season. At the door of the vault the Episcopal Service was read by Mr Hawley— The procession was respectably attended by the friends of the family, and we had all returned home about the setting of the Sun— Mr and Mrs Frye, their Son Thomas, and Mr Thomas B. Johnson accompanied me in the Carriage as the first mourner; at my request Mrs Frye, and Mr Johnson who is an invalid, did not leave the carriage— The state of my own mind was deeply solemn, and greatly affected by the prayer of Mr Smith— In the Evening I wrote to my Son Charles, and mingled my tears with those of my deeply afflicted daughter
26. VI. Sunday.

We had but just returned home last Evening, when there set in a heavy rain, which had been gathering in the clouds the whole day— It continued all Night and the greater part of this day. In the middle of the Night we were alarmed by a fire in the house, first discovered by the smoke making its way into the upper chamber where Mary was lying unable to close her eyes in sleep— She roused Mrs Good, who on going down to the kitchen found the mulatto man Ball, with his hat on—stooping over the table asleep— The table-cloth burnt to a cinder, the table on fire and blazing, and Ball’s coat
sleeve kindling— Mrs Good extinguished the fire; but it was an hour or more before the house, was clear of smoke, and there was a second alarm before the morning, excited by the agitation of the first, but without the same cause— My spirit is awed even to superstitious terror, by these menaces of divine chastisement, mingled with the actual infliction of so many Scourges— I bless the hand that withholds the uplifted blow, and I supplicate for mercy— This morning I attended at St. John’s Church, and took my Grand-child, Fanny with me— Walter Hellen also accompanied me— Mr Hawley read the morning prayer, for the 22d. Sunday after Trinity, and delivered a short exposition upon Romans 8.31—“What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us?— 32. He, that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us all, how shall he not with him also freely give us all things? 33 who shall lay any thing to the charge of God’s elect? It is God that justifieth. 34. Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us 35. Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril or sword? 36. As it is written, for thy sake we are killed all the day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter. 37. Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us. 38 For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities nor Powers, nor things present, nor things to come 39 Nor height; nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the Love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord”— The text itself is a Sermon, and the exposition could scarcely add to its impressiveness. Mr Hawley administered the communion—of which I also partook. In the afternoon I attended the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Smith from Luke 16.31. “And he said unto him, if they hear not Moses and the Prophets, neither will they be persuaded, though one rose from the dead.” Mr Smith’s argument was the all sufficiency of the Scriptures for salvation— In the evening I read the first Sermon of the Volume sent me last Summer, by Mr Henry Colman, on Nature and Revelation, and the second, upon Christianity as taught in the Gospels—but I could give little of my mind to what I read or heard— I answered a Letter which I had yesterday received, from my most distressed wife, written last Tuesday—and I received this day, one from my Son Charles, and one from Elizabeth C. Adams, written on Tuesday.
27. V. Monday.

I had not been out of the house, since my arrival in the City, excepting yesterday to go to Church— This morning I walked round the Capitol hill and garden for exercise. Mr and Mrs Frye were here the greater part of the day: and also W. C. Greenleaf— We began to make the collection of my dear deceased Son’s manuscript Books and Papers, and the examination of them occupied me near the whole of the day— I received and answered a Letter from my dear wife of the 23d: I received also a Letter from Solomon Lincoln of Hingham, enclosing a copy of Resolutions adopted at the Meeting on Monday last of the whig Convention of the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— Approving the course I have held in Congress and
nominating me, as a candidate for re-election as a member of the 24th Congress— In the calamities which oppress me and call for submission to the Will of Heaven, it is cheering consolation to me that the kindness and good will of my neighbours are yet left me— That my public conduct is approved by those who have entrusted their interests to my charge, and that they still have confidence in me— There was to be held on Thursday the 23d. an Antimasonic Convention of the same District to make a nomination, which I have no reason to believe will be different from that of the whigs, though it may prove otherwise. Mr and Mrs Frye, and William C. Greenleaf dined with me—
28. V. Tuesday.

My old morning walk, before breakfast, of four miles, round the Capitol Hill, constitutes the bodily exercise of the day— I took it this morning with some difficulty; but there has been a succession of the finest autumnal weather, from the time when I embarked at Providence till this day, with the exception of Saturday Night and Sunday morning— My daughter, so I shall call the bereaved partner of my dear Son, this day missed for the second time the intermittent chill with which she has been long afflicted— Dr Huntt was here, and I asked him what he thought the fatal disease of my Son was— He did not know.— Doctor Worthington the other physician who attended during the late stage of my Son’s illness was also here, but Mary declined seeing him— William C. Greenleaf, made out from the books a statement of the debts due on the account of the Mills— Mr Frye procured me Kilty’s edition of the Laws of Maryland, which I am to consult with regard to the Administration upon my Son’s Estate; and to the Guardianship of his two children— I wrote upon this subject again to my Son Charles, from whom I received a Letter dated the 24th— With the aid of Walter Hellen I made out a list of all the account Books, both of the concerns of the Wills, and of his household and other pecuniary concerns— I continued also to make a collection of his papers, and made some attempt to assort them— It absorbed the day and left me running into arrearages of my own most indispensable affairs.
29. V. Wednesday

My walk before breakfast round the Capitol-Hill was again made with a difficulty of a different kind from that of yesterday— This day it was a wound in the heel— Mrs Frye spent the day here with Mary; and assisted by Walter Hellen commenced making out a list of the furniture in the house— Michel Antoine Giusta was here twice— He had a note for 800 dollars of my Son, upon interest dated the 12th of July last, and payable in six Months— Antoine wished me to take upon me the debt for one year and make it up 1000 dollars, which I did— I took up my Son’s Note; paid 14 dollars the interest due upon it, and gave Antoine, my note upon interest for 1000 dollars payable in one year— He brought me the balance in silver a large bag—too heavy and too bulky to carry in any ones pocket, and which I
do not incline to keep in the house. Mr W. B. Lawrence paid me a friendly visit and I received him— Mr Frye was here after dinner— I had requested him to ascertain, if the Union Bank at Georgetown where there is a joint debt of my Son John and me of 9000 dollars would make some arrangement for taking any portion of my real Estate here in payment of the whole or part of the debt— He has made the enquiries, but finds them not so disposed— He has enquired also if he could find any person who would take any of the real Estate, and with the consent of the Bank any part of the debt—equally unsuccessful— There is yet one person of whom he is to make enquiry, and he will give me the answer hereafter— With all this my time passes and I am doing nothing— I barely wrote this Evening an answer to a Letter from a Committee of the ΦΓΛ Society of Hamilton College, at Clinton New-York announcing to me my election as an honorary member of the Society— I went this afternoon with Walter Hellen to his brother Johnson’s Office, but did not find him there— I borrowed from his Law Library F. J Troubat’s Edition of Edward Vaughan Williams’s Treatise on the Law of Executors and Administrators, which I am desirous of consulting.
30. V. Thursday.

My morning walk is every day the same— A melancholy pilgrimage in which to divert my thoughts from the bitterness of my misfortunes, I am compelled to seek refuge in errant trifling— That walk has often been attended with pleasing and promising contemplations of hope and joy— Often with the meditations of a tranquil state of mind—sometimes with delightful imaginations of literary composition— Sometimes with deep anxieties, and political disappointments— Never yet with that dark and gloomy terror, and actual anguish which now surrounds me, and from which there is no relief but in the divine mercy— Yet in the midst of this heavy judgment there is Mercy— My own bodily health sustains the shock. My daughter has passed the third day of her intermittent disease without return of the chill. A conscience clear of offence towards man, though with a deep and humiliating sense of my own unworthiness before God, cheers and illuminates the darkness around me. I have no reluctance in prayer, and no drawback to my trust in God— Walter Hellen went this morning to Alexandria, to return to-morrow— Mr Frye dined with me, and Doctor Huntt was here. I find solitude irksome to me, and am yet unable to engage my mind in any useful occupation. I reproach myself for my indolence without overcoming it— I went this morning to the U.S. Branch Bank, deposited there the money that Giusta had left with me, and took my son John’s Bank Book, which was there, and upon which there was a balance in his favour— This evening with great constraint, I wrote two or three hours, for redemption of arrears in this diary— Received a Letter from my Son Charles, written last Sunday Morning before he had received mine to him and to his mother, and that of Mr Frye, announcing to them the fatal termination of my poor Son John’s disease—
31. IV. Friday.

I rose this morning at four O’Clock, and by dint of determined Resolution, after the regular morning reading, sat down, and wrote till broad day-light in this book— It is inexcusable weakness that I cannot so dispose of my own labour every morning, and every day— As Sunrise approached I took my morning walk, and soon after my return received by the mail a Letter from my Son Charles written at Boston
last Monday morning, and soon after breakfast Mr William S. Smith came in. My Letters to my dear wife and to Charles, and that of Mr Frye, written on the day of my beloved Son’s decease, and communicating that event were received at Quincy on Sunday Evening, but Mr and Mrs Smith had just before, arrived there, and from them the mother had received the fatal tidings— Mr T. B. Johnson had written to Mrs Smith who was on a visit at New-York, requesting her to go on immediately to her Sister— They received the Letter at New-York last Saturday at Noon and went in the Steamboat at four the same afternoon— Sunday at seven O’Clock they arrived at Quincy, and Mrs Smith remains there with her Sister— Mr Smith only passed the Night there; came off at four O’Clock the next Morning, and after stopping one day at New-York arrived here last Evening— The Letter from my Son Charles was written on Monday Noon at Boston. He had left his mother, and Mrs Smith with her about ten— She was then calm and composed, and relieved from the agony she had endured by tears— May the mercy of Heaven lighten to her thenceforth this dispensation Edward Wyer came and paid me a visit of an hour— After five years of waiting and of disappointments, he was sent by the good-will of Mr Louis M’Lane just before he retired from the Department of State, last June, as a Messenger, with despatches to the Ministers of the United States in France and Spain— He took out with him the ratification of a Treaty lately concluded with Spain— He returned from Havre to New York, and arrived here three or four days since— He entertained me as usual with the recital of his adventures and hair breadth escapes; and says he cured himself of a severe attack of the Cholera, with sweet oil, cold water, and 60 drops of laudanum— He had the disease at Saragossa, on his return from Madrid to France. He made me also as usual a small present of a new invented French wooded Razor-hone— Walter Hellen returned from Alexandria— Mrs Frye dined here, and spent the day with Mary— Mrs Good was called away to her daughter who has a return of her fits— I had this Evening a friendly visit of two Hours from Mr John Connell of Philadelphia— It was a relief to me, for I find it exceedingly difficult to read or write by Evening Lamplight, and Solitude is then most wearisome and painful.

Day— The first eighteen days of this month were passed at Quincy; my wife very slowly convalescent from a violent and dangerous disease which had confined her to her bed from the 6th. of September— Harrassed with anxiety for my Son and daughter here, knowing them to be ill, but not apprehending immediate danger. On the 18th. a Letter from Walter Hellen called me to the bed side of my Son, where I witnessed only his last hours— Since then I have been unable to resume any regularity of life until this day, when I made an attempt at the occupations suitable for me— But I could barely bring up the arrears of this Diary, and finish an answer which I had begun at Quincy to a Letter from George Bancroft. I have oppressive and difficult and indispensable duties to perform [symbols] may I not be permitted to sink under the burden of them.
